Another form of quantum key transfer is to create pairs of entangled photons, measure one photon from each pair on your side and send the other to your party. When he measures using the same detector configuration, he can extract the same data out of the photons that you did. If an eavesdropper tries to steal the key, he will alter it so you can again detect him before sending the message.

This explains how you can create a secure connection but it doesn't explain one very important aspect, which is trust; A man in the middle may not be able to eavesdrop on an existing secured communication but that doesn't prevent the man in the middle from impersonating the destination that you're creating a secured communication with in the first place. RSA works not only because you can use it to send an encrypted message that only the correct party can read, but more commonly because it can be used with digital signatures which are used to verify ownership of the keys used to encrypt those messages to begin with.

The problem with the one-time pad is you need a truly random numerical key of the same length as the plaintext, which will be very difficult to distribute. Also, the one-time pad does not protect integrity, in fact, it is very suceptable to known-plaintext attacks.
Great video ! Love your work ! I have a question.  Wouldn’t the random activation of detectors be pseudo random ?

The real question is how you can trust people with keys to keep your encrypted information encrypted. It might not matter that much whether Amazon uses RSA/AES/Quantum so long they decrypt the data at some point to share them with third party.

Also when it comes to one time pads, trouble is they need to be as large as the message, so usually you need to send them ahead of the time, it should be fast with quantum cryptography, but to create one time pad for live video feed would still be very hard, even at one second delay you would have to send sligtly over twice as many photons as there are bits in the stream and at times you might need to reduce bitrate because Bob would use the wrong filters and the key would be short... Might take a long while before quantum cryptography is usable for everyday use, as it is now, you will be happy to use it as safer alternative to RSA for exchanging AES keys.

It is true that we build computers that is faster, but that is not the reason why we have to change public key encryption. The reason is that quantum computers works fundamentally different than classical computers. They have the capability of computing algorithms that has polynomial time complexity on a classical computer in polynomial time. So instead of hacking a message in 1000 years, a quantum computer will end up taking a couple seconds instead.

Because when you want to decrypt the message you won't need to factor for it - You'll just need to divide the string by sequential integers until you get a valid message, which has a very small Big O, allowing anyone with a computer to easily crack it. So using prime numbers was utterly meaningless there. And to be even more of a prick, by taking it completely seriously instead of only half, you can tell it's just value shifting (By a multiple of 143) pretty easily since values like 572 appear twice in a row, and all they'd need to do is divide by that value and they'd get the original message instantly, even without a computer. (With a computer, they can easily write a script up in a few minutes to find the multiple by which they change and then divide by that instead).
2:20 im hungry

The increasing speed of normal (ie. non-quantum) computers will have no effect on RSA encryption.  While a faster computer can find factors faster, it can also use larger keys.  Encrypting with a larger key takes less additional computation time than it takes to crack the key.  The faster computers get, the greater the difference in computation time between encryption and cracking.  While quantum computers might throw a big wrench into RSA, that has yet to be seen.
Good luck transmitting quantum sensitive information on the internet. Relays, switches, routers, caching, imperfect fiber... So many obstacles and potential faults it's simply not feasible.

Nice video! However, I should make some important notices:
1 - Quantum Cryptography doesn't exist and (probably) never will, what you are (well) explaining is Quantum Key Distribution
2 - RSA is not so difficult, quantum mechanics are much more, but you explain it pretty well with candies :)
3 - OTP requires special conditions to be perfect, unfortunately just a truly random key isn't enough
4 - In fact, China has already launched a satellite for such purpose and you can even buy some equipment for (not so real) QKD

The #multiply by two primes# method will be easy to break if one had two messages . Find the GCD(Greatest Common Divisor) of the two coded messages and that is the product of the two primes you multiplied with the uncoded message . Divide the code by the GCD and read it aloud . Sorry, but your code with the primes is really bad.
I know you did not want to explain RSA+blockchaining completly, but the oversimplification just hurts and has nothing to do with RSA.
First there is no need for primes or factorisation in this algorithm, since you do not use any property of primes.
Also you still just substitute each character with a number, so it is vulnarable to all attacks used for monoalphabetic, monographic substitution -> cracked by frequency analysis long ago.
Even worse just multipling a factor gives another problem, you just have to calculate the greatest common divisor, which is fast by using the euclidian algorithm, even for large numbers.
So you can easily figure out the key without any intelligent algorithm.

A lot of minute things I think you oversimplified too much in this video... Or in the first case made needlessly complex:

When you told us how you could use prime numbers to encrypt your message (you chose 11 and 13 as prime numbers, and multiplied everything with 11*13 = 143) you aren't actually showing the need for an asymmetric key. In fact you could have used any number, say 144 which is a composite of a lot of 2s and 3s, and the code would work the exact same way. As long as the sender and receiver agrees on the key the encryption works.

The only reason to use one way functions is the much more complex asymmetric algorithms as RSA which i agree very much you shouldn't go into detail on in this kind of video. But for those who are interested basically the product of the primes is PUBLICLY known so anyone can use it to encrypt, but the algorithm is made such that to de-crypt you need to know the prime factors (which you keep private).

The other one is you say that a random number can be used to encrypt a message if it is truly random. This is correct only if the number is as large as the message! There's a big difference between a random number and a random number at least sooo big.

hello Physics Girl, nice show, but flaw with the quantum encryption is that eavesdropper can listen not only to the first part of key generation process, but also to the second part when two sides compare the results, this is where most insecurity is happening...

I heard of an analogy for encryption that went like this: Alice sends a suitcase to Bob, but it has been closed with a lock and only Alice has the key for that lock. When Bob receives the suitcase and checks that Alice's lock is on it, he adds his own lock ,to which only he has the key, and sends the suitcase back to Alice. Once Alice has confirmed that Bob placed his own lock, she opens hers (now the suitcase only has Bob's lock) and sends it back to Bob. Bob can now undo his lock and open the suitcase.

The security there is that keys are never exchanged, Alice can only open her lock ,and Bob can only open his, so even if someone intercepted the suitcase, they'd be unable to open it because the neither Alice nor Bob ever send the keys to each other.

so thats why the rsa key changes every so often

A continuous one time pad is not the goal here. If it were the end system would be spending half its bandwidth just transmitting the key. The end game is a rapidly changing but otherwise much shorter classical ~256 bit symmetric key that is only used to send a few Mb before being discarded.  In this way, even if Moore's law continued and even with quantum computers running Shor's algorithm, you couldn't guess the keys fast enough or the exact point where the stream changes from one key to the next. Quantum error bit rates are currently too high and key transmission rates are too low for continuous keys because your bandwidth could not exceed key generation rate.

So, if diagonal detector is used to determine the state of a vertically polarized photon, then one can have either the right bit or the wrong bit (50/50 chance). So, there is a slight chance that in a very large population even though filters don't match with detectors the string of bits (key) might still get matched totally. Hence, it's not usable on a large scale.
Also, stealing info might be impossible but rendering the communications useless just became a hell lot easier.
Since it's probabilistic, quantum computers are not Gods anymore (can make errors), unlike the conventional ones that is.
So, how are these going to get addressed?
